name: recording
description: An automatic, simple to use, data collection package with a low memory and system footprint, supporting raw data. It’s available for ICT enterprise, industrial and IoT monitoring
description_good_justification: An automatic, simple to use, data collection package with a low memory and system footprint, supporting raw data. It’s available for ICT enterprise, industrial and IoT monitoring
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/blob/master/README.linux
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
report_tracker_justification: For any security vulnerabilities our users will open a CR immediately using https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/issues
report_process_justification: If you have any technical problems, questions or new ideas, please contact us by opening a [new change request] (https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/issues) or if you would like to join our team, https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/blob/master/docs/CONTRIBUTING.md
report_responses_justification: We are conducting a review every month for all open and closed issues under github.
enhancement_responses_justification: We are constantly checking and seeing what defects our users are reporting by closing https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/issues lot of issues.
report_archive_justification: Our change-logs ensure we keep track of all old and current fixes and open problems with our software, each for a separate platform Linux, FreeBSD, Windows, SunOS https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/blob/master/CHANGELOG.linux.txt https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/blob/master/CHANGELOG.freebsd.txt
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: For any security vulnerabilities our users will open a CR immediately using https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/issues
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: For any security vulnerabilities our users will open a CR immediately using https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/issues
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: For any security vulnerabilities our users will open a CR immediately using https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/issues . We are immediately responding to security incidents as found under our Issues page
build_justification: We are proving all necessarily source code and tools to build the KDR project by checking: https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/blob/master/BUILD.ME. We are using in house build management system to continuously build and test KDR along with Jenkins
build_common_tools_justification: We are proving all necessarily source code and tools to build the KDR project by checking: https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/blob/master/BUILD.ME
build_floss_tools_justification: All our software used in KDR is FLOSS. We are proving all necessarily source code and tools to build the KDR project by checking: https://github.com/kronometrix/recording/blob/master/BUILD.ME
test_justification: Majority of all our data recorders have Perl test automated scripts which are responsible to validate and test the functionality of the data recorders.
test_invocation_justification: Majority of all our data recorders have Perl test automated scripts which are responsible to validate and test the functionality of the data recorders. We are using perl (.t) scripts for this.
test_most_justification: We are trying to test all various aspects of code branches, input fields.
test_policy_justification: If we have a new functionality to be added to our project we are starting with a series of simple specs and design notes, followed by developed and a series of test scripts to ensure the original requirement is met and the software behaves correctly.
tests_are_added_justification: We are trying to publish all test automation scripts align with our software. We are trying to improve this part and offer 100% coverage for all our data recorders.
tests_documented_added_justification: This is part of the developer responsibilities - when we have a new module, new recorder being developed the developer must ensure that all test cases are submitted and performed.
warnings_justification: We can build KDR in debug mode to obtain more information if required in case of failures, stress testing, performance testing.
warnings_fixed_justification: Any issues found during the debug mode, we are addressing separately as new issues in github.
warnings_strict_justification: We are trying to reduce all warnings coming from different modules or libraries used by KDR.
know_secure_design_justification: The founder and original developer is dedicated as well for all security aspects of Kronometrix Data Recording software. He is constantly checking forums and mailing lists posting vulnerabilities and critical issues found in software. He is the main designer as well for all secure aspects of KDR.
know_common_errors_justification: The founder and original developer is dedicated as well for all security aspects of Kronometrix Data Recording software.
delivery_mitm_justification: We are using HTTPS and SSH + SCP protocols for this.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: We are trying to issue an immediate security update if we found issues with KDR or with some other 3rd party library used by KDR
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: We are trying to issue an immediate critical updates if we found issues with KDR or with some other 3rd party library used by KDR. In general KDR is used in many production systems and we are required by our customers to act immediately.
static_analysis_justification: We are continuously using Perl::Critic for Kronometrix Data Recording (KDR) software.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: We are continuously using Perl::Critic for Kronometrix Data Recording (KDR) software.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: We are addressing immediately problems found by Perl::Critic and if we are not able to fix them we re-design or include those for a maintenance release.
static_analysis_often_justification: We are using Perl::Critic for all our data recorders as soon as we are changing code. We are trying to rely on its output to write better software.
dynamic_analysis_justification: We are continuously using Perl::Critic for Kronometrix Data Recording (KDR) software.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We are continuously using Perl::Critic along with Devel::NYTPROF to ensure our software is bug free and does not create memory leaks or have security vulnerabilities.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We are trying to use as much as possible Test::Assertions for all runtime assertions.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: Anything we found based on results from Test::Assertions, Devel::NYTProf, Devel::Coverage we are opening as new issues and we address them in a proper manner.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: We are using our in-house build, test and integration system along with Jenkins.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: We are not storing private or confidential information under any public or private repositories.
english_justification: We are providing a simple README documentation where our users can consult and read in English along with very simple instructions how to open defects, issues with the software using as well English language.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Performance Co-Pilot
description: Performance Co-Pilot is a system performance and analysis framework.
contribution_justification: https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/HACKING.md
contribution_requirements_justification:
The project git repo contains detailed information on contribution options as well as expectations of both code submitters and project maintainers:
https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/HACKING.md
https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/qa/README
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
https://pcp.io/documentation.html
Extensive man pages for all utilities, APIs and formats are shipped with the project, and two (open license, freely available) books have been written about PCP.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The master branch of the PCP git repository contains all merged code in-between releases.  The master branch is tagged at pre-determined times, following a week of focused testing ("QA week") with no feature commits - only tests, agreed fixes, and documentation.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/CHANGELOG>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: The release notes document CVE resolutions: <https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/CHANGELOG>.
report_process_justification:
https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/issues
Additionally, PCP maintainers participate in the bug tracking systems used by the Debian, Ubuntu, Fedora and RHEL Linux distributions.
report_archive_justification: https://groups.io/g/pcp - the PCP mailing list is setup to receive notification of all github activity, including commits, new issues and comments on issues.  It thus provides an archive above and beyond that provided by github.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: The vulnerability reporting process is described here: https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/HACKING.md
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The vulnerability reporting process describes a mechanism for contacting the maintainers in private via the maintainers-only list: https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/HACKING.md
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Typically, any security fix is available within 48 hours and (unless embargoes) it will be included in the next release - releases are performed on approximately a six week cycle.
test_justification: An extensive regression test suite is included in the "qa" directory of the project.
tests_are_added_justification: It is self-evident in the commit logs that new tests arrive with new functionality.
tests_documented_added_justification:
This policy is described here: https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/HACKING.md
and This policy is described here: https://github.com/performancecopilot/pcp/blob/master/qa/README
warnings_justification: The PCP build enables all compiler warnings.  Python code is frequently run through pylint.
warnings_strict_justification: While all compiler warnings are enabled (-Wall) we do not fail the build for all warnings as it is not practical for us.  This is because failures from warnings in very new or very old compiler versions have caused headaches for our users in the past.
know_secure_design_justification: The projects primary authors each have been involved with the project for over 20 years, and have been involved in numerous security engagements in that time.  Several of the maintainers have also all liased with the Ubuntu and Red Hat security teams, and resolved issues with their guidance and review.
know_common_errors_justification: All PCP maintainers are aware of the common vulnerabilities in system-level software, and how to mitigate them.
crypto_published_justification: PCP can be (optionally) built with the Mozilla Network Security Services (NSS) cryptographic modules to established encrypted communication channels when performing distributed analysis.
crypto_call_justification: PCP can be (optionally) built with the Mozilla Network Security Services (NSS) cryptographic modules to established encrypted communication channels when performing distributed analysis.
crypto_floss_justification: PCP can be (optionally) built with the Mozilla Network Security Services (NSS) cryptographic modules to established encrypted communication channels when performing distributed analysis.
crypto_keylength_justification: PCP uses Mozilla Network Security Services (NSS) cryptographic module APIs to determine minimum keysize, and then applies that in its use.  These requirements are thus honoured by PCP, and are set by NSS.
crypto_working_justification: PCP does not depend on any cryptographic algorithms.
delivery_mitm_justification: PCP provides for SSL upgrade of its secure connections.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: PCP has had only a handful of CVEs reported in its 20+ years, and each was rapidly fixed, new releases made, and communicated to end users.
static_analysis_justification: Coverity static checking is performed on PCP builds prior to release.
static_analysis_often_justification: Some static checks are performed on every build and associated automated test run, and automated Coverity scans are performed on each build.
dynamic_analysis_justification: The automated regression tests perform dynamic checking in the form of runtime memory checks, runtime thread locking checks using open source tools, as well as performing fault injection into key library routines.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The automated regression tests perform dynamic checking in the form of runtime memory checks, runtime thread locking checks using open source tools.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: The automated regression tests are capable of triggering assertions that are in use in the code base.
general_comments: PCP is an extremely mature software project, being active for well over 20 years now.  It is actively used in many production environments, included in all modern Linux distributions and has ports to a number of other platforms (including Mac OS X, Windows, Solaris, and several flavours of BSD).  The code base has been security audited by both the Ubuntu and Red Hat security teams, and has been offered with customer support by Red Hat Enterprise Linux since RHEL-6.6.  PCP has a passionate group of maintainers, contributors and users and continues to grow and change to this day, and I expect will continue to do so for many years to come.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: PCP does not depend on any cryptographic algorithms.
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.  Discussions on PCP also occur in these public forums:
https://groups.io/g/pcp
https://performancecopilot.slack.com/
and in the #pcp channel on freenode.net (IRC).
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers. // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

floss_license_justification: LGPL license in DESCRIPTION file. R packages avoid repeating texts of known licenses.
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The GitHub repository is the principal development repository.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Semantic versioning used for CRAN releases, fourth component >= 9000 for interim releases.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/r-dbi/DBI/blob/master/NEWS.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Package does not contain compiled code.
report_process_justification: https://github.com/r-dbi/DBI/issues, linked from the main documentation website https://dbi.r-dbi.org/.
report_responses_justification: Acknowledged all bugs that are not self-reported: https://github.com/r-dbi/DBI/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+-author%3Akrlmlr+
enhancement_responses_justification: Only 11 out of 124 not self-reported GitHub issues open: https://github.com/r-dbi/DBI/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+-author%3Akrlmlr+
build_justification: Standard R package with standard building process.
build_floss_tools_justification: Standard R package with standard building process using only R to build.
test_justification: Internal tests in `tests/` directory, test suite for backend packages: https://dbitest.r-dbi.org/
test_invocation_justification: Test suite invoked as part of R CMD check.
test_most_justification: The package is an interface package, most code is exercised by backend tests in https://dbitest.r-dbi.org/ but test coverage is not measured.
test_policy_justification: https://dbitest.r-dbi.org/ is a full specification of the interface.
tests_are_added_justification: The interface specs in https://dbitest.r-dbi.org/ are updated as the interface evolves/stabilizes.
tests_documented_added_justification: We're in the process of reorganizing the test suite, https://github.com/r-dbi/DBI/issues/200#issuecomment-416852116. This will bring the DBI spec to the same place as the interface, and will be easier to document.
warnings_justification: R CMD check checks for best practices.
warnings_fixed_justification: No WARNINGs or NOTEs with CRAN checks: https://cran.r-project.org/web/checks/check_results_DBI.html
know_secure_design_justification: Quoting identifiers and literals for SQL queries to avoid SQL injection is a key concept of DBI.
know_common_errors_justification: Quoting identifiers and literals for SQL queries to avoid SQL injection is a key concept of DBI.
static_analysis_justification: No static code analysis tool known.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: No static code analysis tool known.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: No static code analysis tool known.
static_analysis_often_justification: No static code analysis tool known.
dynamic_analysis_justification: No dynamic code analysis tool known.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Run-time assertions included, but not checked.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Testing on Travis CI uses transient databases.
english_justification: English is the default language on GitHub.

name: libbsd
description: Utility functions from BSD systems
license: (BSD-4-Clause AND BSD-3-Clause AND BSD-2-Clause AND MIT AND ISC AND Beerware)
contribution_justification: https://libbsd.freedesktop.org
license_location_justification: https://cgit.freedesktop.org/libbsd/tree/COPYING
floss_license_osi_justification: The project includes BSD-4-Clause and Beerware licenses.
documentation_basics_justification: Every function comes with a man page.
repo_distributed_justification: The project uses git.
version_semver_justification: The versioning is close, but not entirely follows SemVer, and that seems fine.
release_notes_justification: The releases are announced on FreeDesktop.Org mailing lists, f.ex., <https://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/libbsd/2018-May/000190.html>.
report_responses_justification: All past bugs have been fixed.
enhancement_responses_justification: All past reports have been responded.
test_invocation_justification: The project uses autotools, and the test suite can be called via «make check». https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd
tests_are_added_justification: While the test suite is still work in progress and does not have full coverage as tests need to be added for old functions, even though the code has been in use in multiple BSDs and receives substantial testing there. New and old code is getting new unit tests.
warnings_strict_justification: Sets many compiler warnings by default. https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd/-/blob/main/configure.ac
static_analysis_often_justification: This is done at least once before every release.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The only cryptographic primitive in the library is arc4random, which uses Chacha20.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: GitLab Pipelines are used on each commit. https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd/pipelines
discussion_justification:
https://lists.freedesktop.org/mailman/listinfo/libbsd
https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd/issues
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
roles_responsibilities_justification: The current maintainer is listed on the project page. https://libbsd.freedesktop.org/wiki/
access_continuity_justification: The project is hosted at freedesktop.org, so the admins there could grant access to other persons. https://gitlab.freedesktop.org
bus_factor_justification: The project only has one member.
documentation_architecture_justification: The project provides a libbsd(7) man page describing the overall project. https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd/-/blob/main/man/libbsd.7
documentation_quick_start_justification: The project provides a man page for the overall shared library, as libbsd(7). https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd/-/blob/main/man/libbsd.7
documentation_current_justification: All functions are documented as part of the project man pages.
documentation_achievements_justification:
Appropriate badges are shown on the home page and gitlab project page.

https://libbsd.freedesktop.org/wiki/
https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd
sites_password_security_justification: The project site is based on gitlab.
maintenance_or_update_justification: Upgrading to the latest version should always be supported and easy, given that backwards ABI and API compatibility are taken very seriously, to the point that the SOVERSION of the shared library has not yet been bumped.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: Reporters for security issues are always credited in the commit messages. See https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd/commits/master.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: Because the project imports various source files from external projects, enforcing a single coding style would be disruptive and cause unnecessary merge conflict. https://libbsd.freedesktop.org/
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Each push triggers a test suite run. https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libbsd/libbsd/pipelines
signed_releases_justification: Every released tarball is OpenPGP signed.
contributors_unassociated_justification: The project only has one member.
copyright_per_file_justification: Each file contains copyright statement information.
license_per_file_justification: Each file contains a license header.
require_2FA_justification: The project uses 2FA to manage the project.
secure_2FA_justification: The 2FA used is either a hardware token or TOTP.
